creator: apache@bakerweb.biz
text:
All of the type-map files in the /manual/ directory are lacking the VAR
extension (they are just named with an HTML extension). That makes all requests
to directory roots under and including /manual/ return the type-map file to the
browser.

It's not limited to directory roots. It's ALL files unless you directly type in
the file you want with the proper language extension. In other words,
client-side user-parsed content-negotiation ;)
creator: apache@bakerweb.biz

text:
This is already since 2.0. There's an extra config snippet in the distribution,
which configures the httpd properly to let mod_negotiation parse the *.html
files as variant files (and more). The only thing is that 2.2 no longer does
include it automatically in the main config (it's commented out).
creator: nd@perlig.de
apache@bakerweb.biz
text: So ASF wants the default config to fail? Why is this invalid?

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
The default config doesn't include the manual at all; you can't browse it. Is
does not fail.

creator: apache@bakerweb.biz
text: When I build InstallBin, it sure does include the manual.

The manual is installed, of course. The httpd.conf does not include the manual
directory as it is *commented out*, though.

I get the feeling, I'm missing something here. Can you show your config, which
includes the manual in the httpd.conf?
creator: nd@perlig.de
apache@bakerweb.biz
text:
No, the manual is not configured to be accessed through the browser by default,
but it is not useable by local acces either. Users opening index.html will be
very surprised to see a type-map file displayed in their browser window (with no
line-breaks I might add). Even if they figure out to open index.html.en,
following links in the manual will not work.

As said, this is the case since 2.0 and not new in 2.2 (btw, the 1.3 manual
isn't viewable offline either).

There are separate offline packages for download:
http://www.apache.org/dyn/closer.cgi/httpd/docs/
creator: nd@perlig.de
apache@bakerweb.biz
text:
Ok, we are back to my original question: Does the ASF want the official default
configuration to be that the manual is installed but there is no way to use it?
If so, why?

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
Of course not. There is a way to use it: just uncomment the line in the
httpd.conf if you want it.

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
Furthermore, this kind of questions should be discussed on dev@httpd. For now
it's the intended behaviour and therefore marked invalid.

If I uncomment the lines in the conf file, that's no longer the default
configuration. It's fine if ASF wants it that way, but it just seems strange to
have a default config that is useless.
creator: apache@bakerweb.biz
